                                    Well-known US pro-life activist-priest dismissed from priesthood
        





Frank Pavone, a Trump supporter and national director of anti-abortion group Priests for Life, dismissed because of “blasphemous communications”, “persistent disobedience"





                        By Ivan Fernandes                    





                   December 19, 2022 at 10:24 AM GMT+1,
                        updated  December 19, 2022 at 11:08 AM GMT+1

The Vatican has dismissed from the clerical state a U.S. priest who is a well-known pro-life activist and national director of the anti-abortion group Priests for Life because of his “blasphemous communications on social media” as well as “persistent disobedience of the lawful instructions of his diocesan bishop.” 
Frank Pavone, 63, was ordained as a priest in the New York Archdiocese in 1988, moving to the Diocese of Amarillo, Texas, in 2005. Since 1993, Pavone has been the national director of the pro-life movement Priests for Life, which claims to be the "biggest ministry in the Catholic Church devoted on ending abortion". 
Pavone, a steadfast Trump supporter and whose Twitter handle still has a picture of the former president, earlier had been admonished by Bishop Patrick Zurek of Amarillo for his partisan activism as former advisory board member of the group "Catholics for Trump" in 2016 and a co-chair of Trump’s 2020 pro-life coalition. Canon law forbids clerics from having an active role in political parties without permission from their bishop. 

    "Father Pavone had no reasonable justification for his actions"

In 2016, Pavone was reprimanded for placing an aborted fetus on an altar and sharing a video of it on two social media platforms. The post that accompanied the video said Trump and the Republican Party sought to protect unborn children while Hillary Clinton and the Democratic Party would enable abortion to continue. Bishop Zurek had already placed limitations on Pavone’s ministry since 2011 but the priest managed to appeal those sanctions. 
Now, Archbishop Christophe Pierre, apostolic nuncio to the United States, told the US Catholic bishops in a letter that there was no chance for Pavone to appeal the decision taken by the Vatican on November 9. “Father Pavone was given ample opportunity to defend himself in the canonical proceedings, and he was also given multiple opportunities to submit himself to the authority of his diocesan bishop. It was determined that Father Pavone had no reasonable justification for his actions,” explains a statement attached to the nuncio's letter.
The statement also said that since Priests for Life “is not a Catholic organization”, Pavone’s continuing role in it as a lay person would be entirely up to the leadership of that organization. Originally based in Staten Island, New York, Priests for Life is now headquartered in Titusville, Florida. The organization has also been embroiled in management and financial scandals. 






Despite his dismissal from the clerical state, Pavone has in a social media video promised to continue the anti-abortion "battle" and decried the "cancel culture" of the church, which he claimed had harassed him for decades. Also, in a statement on his Priest for Life website, Pavone claimed that his laicization, whereby he can no longer present himself as a Catholic priest, was "the product of an oppressive process" and that he was thinking about taking unspecified legal action against unnamed U.S. bishops. 
Pavone was also in the forefront of putting abortion above all other issues, joining in the insistence that it's okay for Catholics to favor the death penalty. "Regarding the death penalty, if there is a growing consensus that we should not kill the guilty, let's get everyone on board that we should not kill the innocent! (This is for you, Democrat Party!)", he had tweeted. 
This year Pavone celebrated the 35th anniversary of his regular television show, "Defending Life," on EWTN (Eternal Word Television Network), a U.S. cable television network that presents around-the-clock Catholic-themed programming known its for its partisan political focus and anti-Pope Francis coverage.
